DOCNAME: CASE OF McCANN AND OTHERS v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 2;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Costs and expenses partial award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The facts set out below , established by the ORG in its report of CARDINAL DATE ( see paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL below ) , are drawn mainly from the transcript of evidence given at the NORP inquest ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . DATE , and probably from DATE , GPE , NORP and GPE authorities were aware that the Provisional IRA ( ORG - " IRA " ) were planning a terrorist attack on ORG . It appeared from the intelligence received and from observations made by the LOC police that the target was to be the assembly area south of FAC where ORG usually assembled to carry out the changing of the guard DATE at TIME .

CARDINAL . Prior to CARDINAL DATE , an advisory group was formed to advise and assist Mr PERSON , the NORP Commissioner of Police ( " the Commissioner " ) . It consisted of Soldier F ( senior military adviser and officer in ORG or " ORG " ) , Soldier E ( ORG attack commander ) , Soldier G ( bomb - disposal adviser ) , PERSON ( Acting Deputy Commissioner of Police ) , Detective Chief Inspector PERSON , attached to GPE , and ORG officers . The Commissioner issued instructions for an operational order to be prepared to deal with the situation .

CARDINAL . Soldier F and his group , including Soldier E and a number of other ORG soldiers , had arrived in GPE prior to CARDINAL DATE . Preliminary briefings had been conducted by ORG in GPE . According to the military rules of engagement ( entitled " Rules of ORG for the Military Commander in Operation Flavius " ) issued to Soldier F by ORG , the purpose of the military forces being in GPE was to assist the NORP police to arrest the IRA active service unit ( " ASU " ) should the police request such military intervention . The rules also instructed ORG to operate as directed by the Commissioner .
CARDINAL . The rules also specified the circumstances in which the use of force by the soldiers would be permissible as follows :
" Use of force

CARDINAL . You and your men will not use force unless requested to do so by the senior police officer(s ) designated by the GPE Police Commissioner ; or unless it is necessary to do so in order to protect life . You and your men are not then to use more force than is necessary in order to protect life ... Opening fire

CARDINAL . You and your men may only open fire against a person if you or they have reasonable grounds for believing that he / she is currently committing , or is about to commit , an action which is likely to endanger your or their lives , or the life of any other person , and if there is no other way to prevent this .
Firing without warning

CARDINAL . You and your men may fire without warning if the giving of a warning or any delay in firing could lead to death or injury to you or them or any other person , or if the giving of a warning is clearly impracticable .
Warning before firing

CARDINAL . If the circumstances in paragraph CARDINAL do not apply , a warning is necessary before firing . The warning is to be as clear as possible and is to include a direction to surrender and a clear warning that fire will be opened if the direction is not obeyed . "

CARDINAL . The operational order of the Commissioner , which was drawn up on DATE , stated that it was suspected that a terrorist attack was planned in GPE and that the target was highly probably the band and guard of ORG during a ceremonial changing of the guard at FAC on DATE . It stated that there were " indications that the method to be used is by means of explosives , probably using a car bomb " . The intention of the operation was then stated to be
" ( a ) to protect life ;
( b ) to foil the attempt ;
( c ) to arrest the offenders ;
( d ) the securing and safe custody of the prisoners " .

CARDINAL . The methods to be employed were listed as police surveillance and having sufficient personnel suitably equipped to deal with any contingency . It was also stated that the suspects were to be arrested by using minimum force , that they were to be disarmed and that evidence was to be gathered for a court trial . Annexed to the order were , inter alia , lists of attribution of police personnel , firearms rules of engagement and a guide to firearms use by police ( see paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . A plan for evacuation of the expected area of attack was drawn up on DATE by Chief Inspector PERSON . It was to be put into effect on DATE ( DATE ) . It included arrangements to evacuate and cordon off the area around FAC to a radius of QUANTITY , identified the approach roads to be closed , detailed the necessary traffic diversions and listed the personnel to implement the plan . The plan was not , however , distributed to other officers .

CARDINAL . The operation in GPE to counter the expected terrorist attack was run from a joint operations room in the centre of GPE . In the operations room there were CARDINAL distinct groups - the army or military group ( comprising the ORG and bomb - disposal personnel ) , a police group and the surveillance or security service group . Each had its own means of communication with personnel on the ground operated from a separate control station . The CARDINAL principal means of communication in use were , however , the CARDINAL radio - communication networks known as the surveillance net and the tactical or military net . There was a bomb - disposal net which was not busy and , while the police had a net , it was not considered secure and a telephone appears to have been used for necessary communications with the central police station .
CARDINAL . On DATE , there was a reported sighting of the ORG in GPE in GPE . As the Commissioner was not sure how or when they would come to NORP surveillance was mounted .

CARDINAL . At TIME DATE , the Commissioner held a briefing which was attended by officers from ORG ( including from the surveillance team Witnesses H , I , J , K , L , M and N ) , military personnel ( including Soldiers A , B , C , D , E , F and G ) and members of the NORP police ( Officers P , Q and R and Detective Chief Inspector GPE , Head of Special Branch , and Detective Constable PERSON ) .

The Commissioner conducted the police aspect of the briefing , the members of the Security Services briefed on the intelligence aspects of the operation , the head of the surveillance team covered the surveillance operation and Soldier E explained the role of the military if they were called on for assistance . It then appears that the briefing split into smaller groups , E continuing to brief the soldiers under his command but in the same location .
The Commissioner also explained the rules of engagement and firearms procedures and expressed the importance to the police of gathering evidence for a subsequent trial of the terrorists .
CARDINAL . The briefing by the representative of the Security Services included inter alia the following assessments :
( a ) the IRA intended to attack the changing of the guard ceremony in the assembly area outside FAC on the morning of DATE ;

( b ) an ORG of CARDINAL would be sent to carry out the attack , consisting of PERSON , PERSON and a third member , later positively identified as PERSON . ORG had been previously convicted and sentenced to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment for possession of explosives . ORG had previously been convicted and sentenced to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment for causing explosions . She was known during her time in prison to have been the acknowledged leader of the IRA wing of prisoners . Savage was described as an expert bomb - maker . Photographs were shown of the CARDINAL suspects ;
( c ) the CARDINAL individuals were believed to be dangerous terrorists who would almost certainly be armed and who , if confronted by security forces , would be likely to use their weapons ;
( d ) the attack would be by way of a car bomb . It was believed that the bomb would be brought across the border in a vehicle and that it would remain hidden inside the vehicle ;

( e ) the possibility that a " blocking " car - i.e. a car not containing a bomb but parked in the assembly area in order to reserve a space for the car containing the bomb - would be used had been considered , but was thought unlikely .

This possibility was discounted , according to Senior Security Services Officer O in his evidence to the inquest , since ( CARDINAL ) it would involve CARDINAL trips ; ( CARDINAL ) it would be unnecessary since parking spaces would be available on TIME or on a DATE TIME ; ( CARDINAL ) there was the possibility that the blocking car would itself get blocked by careless parking . The assessment was that the ORG would drive in at the last moment on TIME or on TIME . On the other hand Chief Inspector PERSON , who was not present at the briefing , stated that he would not have brought in a bomb on DATE since it would be busy and difficult to find a parking place .

CARDINAL . Various methods of detonation of the bomb were mentioned at the briefing : by timing device , by ORG ( radio - controlled improvised explosive device ) and by command wire . This last option which required placing a bomb connected to a detonator by a wire was discounted as impracticable in the circumstances . The use of a timer was , according to O , considered highly unlikely in light of the recent IRA explosion of a bomb by timer device at ORG which had resulted in a high number of civilian casualties . Use of a remote - control device was considered to be far more likely since it was safer from the point of view of the terrorist who could get away from the bomb before it exploded and was more controllable than a timer which once activated was virtually impossible to stop .

CARDINAL . The recollection of the others present at the briefing differs on this point . The police witnesses remembered both a timer and a remote - control device being discussed . The Commissioner and his Deputy expected either type of device . Chief Inspector PERSON recalled specific mention of the remote - control device as being more likely . The surveillance officers also thought that an emphasis was placed on the use of a remote - control device .

CARDINAL . The military witnesses in contrast appear to have been convinced that it would certainly be a remote - control device . Soldier F made no mention of a timer but stated that they were briefed that it was to be a " button job " , that is , radio - controlled so that the bomb could be detonated at the press of a button . He believed that there had been an IRA directive not to repeat the carnage of a recent bomb in LOC and to keep to a minimum the loss of life to innocent civilians . It was thought that the terrorists knew that if it rained the parade would be cancelled and in that event , if a timer was used , they would be left with a bomb that would go off indiscriminately .

Soldier E also stated that at the briefing they were informed that the bomb would be initiated by a " button job " . In answer to a question by a juror , he stated that there had been discussion with the soldiers that there was more chance that they would have to shoot to kill in view of the very short time factor which a " button job " would impose .
CARDINAL . Soldiers A , B , C and D stated that they were told at the briefing that the device would be radio - controlled . Soldier C said that E stressed to them that it would be a " button job " .
CARDINAL . Soldier O stated that it was considered that , if the means of detonation was by radio control , it was possible that the suspects might , if confronted , seek to detonate the device .

Soldier F also recalled that the assessment was that any one of the CARDINAL could be carrying a device . In answer to a question pointing out the inconsistency of this proposition with the assessment that the ORG wished to minimise civilian casualties , ORG stated that the terrorists would detonate in order nonetheless to achieve some degree of propaganda success . He stated that the briefing by the intelligence people was that it was likely if the terrorists were cornered they would try to explode the bomb .

Soldier E confirmed that they had been told that the CARDINAL suspects were ruthless and if confronted would resort to whatever weapons or " button jobs " they carried . He had particularly emphasised to his soldiers that there was a strong likelihood that CARDINAL of the suspects would be carrying a " button job " .

CARDINAL . This was recalled , in substance , by Soldiers C and PERSON B did not remember being told that they would attempt to detonate if arrested but was aware of that possibility in his own mind . They were warned that the suspects were highly dangerous , dedicated and fanatical .

CARDINAL . It does not appear that there was any discussion at the briefing as to the likely size , mode of activation or range of a remote - control device that might be expected . The soldiers appear to have received information at their own briefings . Soldier F did not know the precise size a radio detonator might be , but had been told that the device would be small enough to conceal on the person . Soldier D was told that the device could come in a small size and that it could be detonated by the pressing of just CARDINAL button .

CARDINAL . As regards the range of the device , Soldier F said that the military were told that the equipment which the IRA had was capable of detonating a radio - controlled bomb over a distance of QUANTITY and a half .

CARDINAL . The operations room opened at TIME . The Commissioner was on duty there from TIME . When he left , Deputy Commissioner PERSON took his place . Members of the surveillance teams were on duty in the streets of GPE as were Soldiers A , B , C and D and members of the police force involved in the operation . Soldiers A , B , C and D were in civilian clothing and were each armed with a QUANTITY pistol which was carried in the rear waistband of their trousers . Each also carried a radio concealed on their person . They were working in pairs . In each pair , CARDINAL was in radio communication on the tactical net and the other on the surveillance net . Police officers P , Q and R , who were on duty to support the soldiers in any arrest , were also in plain clothes and armed .

CARDINAL . On DATE , at TIME , Detective Constable PERSON went to the frontier to keep observation for the CARDINAL suspects from the computer room at the NORP immigration post . He was aware of the real names of the CARDINAL suspects and had been shown photographs . The NORP officers had photographs . The computer room was at some distance from the frontier crossing point itself . The NORP officers at the immigration post showed him passports by means of a visual aid unit . It appears that they only showed him the passports of those cars containing CARDINAL men and CARDINAL woman . Several pictures were flashed up for him during the course of DATE but he did not recognise them . At the inquest , under cross - examination , he at first did not recall that he had been given any of the aliases that the CARDINAL suspects might be employing . Then , however , he thought that he remembered the name of PERSON being mentioned in relation to PERSON and that at the time he must have known the aliases of all CARDINAL , as must the NORP officers . Chief Inspector PERSON , who had briefed Huart however , had no recollection of the name of PERSON being mentioned before DATE and he only recalled the name of PERSON in respect of PERSON . However , if PERSON recalled it , he did not doubt that it was so .

CARDINAL . On the GPE side of the border , the customs officers and police normally on duty were not informed or involved in the surveillance on the basis that this would involve information being provided to an excessive number of people . No steps were taken to slow down the line of cars as they entered or to scrutinise all passports since it was felt that this might put the suspects on guard . There was , however , a separate surveillance team at the border and , in the area of the airfield nearby , an arrest group . Witness M who led a surveillance team at the frontier expressed disappointment at the apparent lack of co - operation between the various groups involved in GPE but he understood that matters were arranged that way as a matter of security .
CARDINAL . At the inquest , Chief Inspector PERSON stated , when pressed about the failure to take more scrupulous measures on the GPE side ,

" In this particular case , we are talking about dangerous terrorists . We were talking about a very , very major and delicate operation - an operation that had to succeed . I think the only way it could have succeeded is to allow the terrorists to come in and for the terrorists to have been dealt with in the way they were dealt with as far as the surveillance is concerned . "

CARDINAL . While Soldiers E and F made reference to the preferred military option as being to intercept and arrest the suspects in the frontier area , it appears not to have been pursued with any conviction , on the assumption that identification would not be possible in light of the brief time available for identification to be made ( TIME per car ) and the lack of prior warning from the NORP side .

CARDINAL . Soldier F stated that the military option had been refined down to the preferred option of arresting the suspects when they were on foot in the assembly area , to disarm them and then to defuse the bomb . He referred also to CARDINAL key indicators formulated by ORG with a view to guiding the Commissioner :
CARDINAL . if a car was driven into GPE and parked in the assembly area by an identified member of the active service unit ;
CARDINAL . if a car was driven into the assembly area by an ORG member without prior warning ;
CARDINAL . the presence in GPE of the other members of the ORG ;
CARDINAL . if there was clear indication that terrorists having parked their car bomb intended to leave GPE , that is to say , they were heading for the border .

The plan was for an arrest to be carried out once all the members of the ORG were present and identified and they had parked a car which they intended to leave . Any earlier action was considered premature as likely to raise suspicion in any unapprehended members of the ORG with possible risk resulting and as leaving no evidence for the police to use in court .

CARDINAL . Detective Constable PERSON was on surveillance duty in a bank which had a view over the area in which the car driven in by the terrorists was expected to be parked . At TIME , he heard a report over the surveillance net that a car had parked in a parking space in the assembly area under observation . A member of ORG commented that the driver had taken time to get out and fiddled with something between the seats . PERSON saw the man lock the car door and walk away towards FAC . CARDINAL of the ORG officers present consulted a colleague as to possible identification but neither was sure . A field officer was requested to confirm the identity . DC PERSON could not himself identify the man from his position .

CARDINAL . Witness N of the ORG team on surveillance in the car - park in the assembly area recalled that at TIME a white ORG car drove up and parked , the driver getting out after TIME and walking away . A young man resembling the suspect was spotted next at TIME in the area . Witness H , who was sent to verify his identification , saw the suspect at about that time and recognised him as Savage without difficulty . ORG also saw the suspect at the rear of PERSON and at TIME reported over the radio to the operations room that he identified him as PERSON and also as the man who had earlier parked the car in the assembly area .
Officer Q who was on duty on the street recalled hearing over the surveillance net at TIME that Savage had been identified .

CARDINAL . The Commissioner however did not recollect being notified about the identification of Savage until he arrived in the operations room at TIME . GPE did not recall hearing anything about PERSON either until it was reported that he had met up with CARDINAL other suspects at TIME . Soldiers E and F recalled however that a possible sighting of Savage was reported at TIME . Soldier G also refers to the later sighting at TIME as the first identification of Savage .

CARDINAL . There appears to have been a certain time - lag between information on the ground either being received in the operations room or being passed on . Soldiers E and F may have been more aware than the Commissioner of events since they were monitoring closely the information coming in over the nets , which apparently was not audible to the Commissioner where he sat at a table away from the control stations . DATE . The suspect was followed for TIME by Witness H who recalled that the suspect was using anti - surveillance techniques such as employing devious routes through the side streets . Witness N was also following him , for TIME , and considered that he was alert and taking precautions , for example stopping round the corner at the end of alleyways to see who followed .

CARDINAL . Witness M who was leading the surveillance at the border stated that CARDINAL suspects passed the frontier at TIME though apparently they were initially not clearly identified . They were on foot and reportedly taking counter - surveillance measures ( PERSON looking back frequently ) . Their progress into GPE was followed .
CARDINAL . At TIME , Soldiers E and F recalled a message being received that there was a possible sighting of GPE and PERSON entering on foot . The Commissioner was immediately informed .

CARDINAL . At TIME , it was reported to the operations room that the suspects PERSON and PERSON had met with a second man identified as the suspect PERSON and that the CARDINAL were looking at a white ORG car in the car - park in the assembly area .

Witness H stated that the CARDINAL suspects spent some considerable time staring across to where a car had been parked , as if , in his assessment , they were studying it to make sure it was absolutely right for the effect of the bomb . PERSON also witnessed the CARDINAL suspects meeting in the area of the car - park , stating that all CARDINAL turned and stared towards where the car was parked . He gave the time TIME . He stated that the ORG made identification of all CARDINAL at this moment .

At this moment , the possibility of effecting an arrest was considered . There were different recollections . Mr GPE stated that he was asked whether he would hand over control to the military for the arrest but that he asked whether the suspects had been positively identified ; he was told that there was PERCENT identification . Almost immediately the CARDINAL suspects moved away from the car through FAC . He recalled that the movement of the CARDINAL suspects towards the south gave rise to some discussion as to whether this indicated that the CARDINAL suspects were on reconnaissance and might return for the car . It was for this reason that the decision was taken not to arrest at this point .

CARDINAL . At TIME , Mr GPE rang the Commissioner to inform him that it was more and more likely to be ORG and PERSON . When the Commissioner arrived shortly afterwards , Mr GPE informed him that the suspects PERSON and PERSON had met up with a third person thought to be Savage and that an arrest had almost been made .

CARDINAL . The Commissioner asked for positive identification of the CARDINAL suspects . Identification was confirmed by TIME when it was reported to the operations room that the CARDINAL suspects had returned to the assembly area and gone past looking at the car again . The CARDINAL suspects continued north and away from the car . Soldiers E and F recalled that control was passed to the military but immediately taken back as the Commissioner requested further verification of the identities of the suspects . The confirmation of identity which the Commissioner had requested was received almost immediately .

CARDINAL . After the CARDINAL ORG identities had been confirmed and they had moved away from the assembly area , Soldier G examined the suspect car . He conducted an examination from the exterior without touching the car . He described it as a newish - looking white ORG . He detected nothing untoward inside the car or anything visibly out of place or concealed under the seats . He noted that the aerial of the car , which was rusty , was out of place with the age of the car . He was in the area for TIME . He returned to the operations room and reported to the Commissioner that he regarded the car as a " suspect car bomb " . At the inquest , he explained that this was a term of art for a car parked in suspicious circumstances where there is every reason to believe that it is a car bomb and that it could not be said that it was not a car bomb .

DATE . The Commissioner recalled that G had reported that it was a suspect car bomb since there was an old aerial situated centrally of a relatively new car . He stated that as a result they treated it as a " possible car bomb " .
CARDINAL . Soldier F referred to the aerial as rendering the car suspicious and stated that this information was passed on to all the parties on the ground .
CARDINAL . Soldier E was more categorical and stated that as far as G could tell " from a cursory visual examination he was able to confirm our suspicion that they were dealing with a car bomb " .

CARDINAL . Soldier A stated that he believed MONEY that there was a bomb in the debussing area , that the suspects had remote - control devices and were probably armed . This was what he had been told over the radio . Soldier C recalled that it had been confirmed by Soldier E that there was a device in GPE ’s LOC which could be detonated by CARDINAL of CARDINAL suspects who was more likely to be Savage because he had been seen " fiddling " with something in the car earlier . He had also been told of the indication of an old aerial on a new car .

Soldier D said that it had been confirmed to him by Soldier E that there was a bomb there . To his recollection , no one told them that there was a possibility that the CARDINAL suspects might not be carrying the remote - control devices with them on the DATE or that possibly they had not brought a bomb in . He had been told by Soldier E - whom he fully trusted - that there was a bomb in the car .

CARDINAL . At the inquest Soldier G was described as being the bomb - disposal adviser . He had experience of dealing with car bombs in GPE but at the inquest he stated in reply to various questions that he was neither a radio - communications expert nor an explosives expert . He had not thought of de - activating the suspect bomb by unscrewing the aerial from the car . When it was put to him in cross - examination , he agreed that to have attempted to unscrew the aerial would have been potentially dangerous .

CARDINAL . After receiving the report from Soldier G and in view of the fact that the CARDINAL suspects were continuing northwards leaving the car behind , the Commissioner decided that the CARDINAL suspects should be arrested on suspicion of conspiracy to murder . At TIME , he signed a form requesting the military to intercept and apprehend the suspects . The form , which had been provided in advance by the military , stated :

" I , PERSON , Commissioner of Police , having considered the terrorist situation in GPE and having been fully briefed on the military plan with firearms , request that you proceed with the military option which may include the use of lethal force for the preservation of life . "
After the form was signed , Soldier F walked across to the tactical net and issued instructions that the military should intervene .

Soldier E ascertained the positions of the soldiers by radio . Soldiers C and D had been visually monitoring the movement of the CARDINAL suspects in FAC and FAC . Soldiers A and B were making their way north through FAC and into the GPE tunnel . The soldiers were informed that control had passed to them to make an arrest .

CARDINAL . The evidence at the inquest given by the soldiers and Police Officer R and ORG was that the soldiers had practised arrest procedures on several occasions with the police before DATE . According to these rehearsals , the soldiers were to approach the suspects to within a close distance , cover the suspects with their pistols and shout " Stop . Police . Hands up . " or words to that effect . They would then make the suspects lie on the ground with their arms away from their bodies until the police moved in to carry out a formal arrest . Further , ORG stated that special efforts had been made to identify a suitable place in GPE for the terrorists to be held in custody following their arrest .

CARDINAL . On reaching the junction of ORG with ORG , the CARDINAL suspects crossed the road and stopped on the other side talking . Officer R , observing , saw them appear to exchange newspapers . At this point , Soldiers C and D were approaching the junction from ORG . Soldiers A and B emerging from GPE tunnel also saw the CARDINAL suspects at the junction from their position where the pathway to the tunnel joined ORG .

CARDINAL . As the soldiers converged on the junction , however , Savage split away from suspects ORG and PERSON turning south towards the GPE tunnel . ORG and PERSON continued north up the right - hand pavement of FAC .

CARDINAL . Savage passed Soldiers A and B , brushing against the shoulder of PERSON B was about to turn to effect the arrest but A told him that they should continue towards suspects PERSON and PERSON , knowing that C and D were in the area and that they would arrest Savage . Soldiers C and D , aware that A and B were following suspects PERSON and PERSON , crossed over from ORG and followed Savage .
CARDINAL . The evidence of Soldiers A and B at the inquest was to the following effect .

CARDINAL . Soldiers A and B continued north up FAC after ORG and PERSON , walking at a brisk pace to close the distance . PERSON was walking on the right of PERSON on the inside of the pavement . He was wearing white trousers and a white shirt , without any jacket . PERSON was dressed in a skirt and jacket and was carrying a large handbag .

CARDINAL . When Soldier A was QUANTITY ( though maybe closer ) behind PERSON on the inside of the pavement , ORG looked back over his left shoulder . ORG appeared to look directly at A and the smile left his face , as if he had a realisation of who A was and that he was a threat .

Soldier A drew his pistol , intending to shout a warning to stop at the same time , though he was uncertain if the words actually came out . ORG ’s hand moved suddenly and aggressively across the front of his body . A thought that he was going for the button to detonate the bomb and opened fire . He shot CARDINAL round into ORG ’s back from a distance of QUANTITY ( though maybe it may have been closer ) . Out of the corner of his eye , A saw a movement by PERSON . ORG had been walking on the left of ORG on the side of the pavement next to the road . A saw her make a CARDINAL turn to the right towards PERSON , grabbing for her handbag which was under her left arm . A thought that she was also going for a button and shot CARDINAL round into her back . He did not disagree when it was put to him that the forensic evidence suggested that he may have shot from a distance of QUANTITY ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . Then A turned back to PERSON and shot him once more in the body and twice in the head . A was not aware of B opening fire as this was happening . He fired a total of CARDINAL shots .

CARDINAL . Soldier B was approaching directly behind PERSON on the road side of the pavement . He was watching her . When they were CARDINAL metres away and closing , he saw in his peripheral vision that PERSON turned his head to look over his shoulder . He heard what he presumed was a shout from A which he thought was the start of the arrest process . At almost the same instant , there was firing to his right . Simultaneously , PERSON made a sharp movement to her right , drawing the bag which she had under her left arm across her body . He could not see her hands or the bag and feared that she was going for the button . He opened fire on ORG . He deemed that ORG was in a threatening position and was unable to see his hands and switched fire to ORG . Then he turned back to PERSON and continued firing until he was certain that she was no longer a threat , namely , her hands away from her body . He fired a total of CARDINAL shots .

CARDINAL . Both soldiers denied that ORG or ORG made any attempt to surrender with their hands up in the air or that they fired at the CARDINAL suspects when they were lying on the ground . At the inquest , Soldier A stated expressly that his intention had been to kill ORG " to stop him becoming a threat and detonating that bomb " .
CARDINAL . The shooting took place on the pavement in front of a ORG petrol station in FAC .

After the shooting , the soldiers put on berets so they would be recognised by the police . They noticed a police car , with its siren going , coming south from the sundial down the far side of PERSON . A number of policemen jumped out of the car and leapt the central barrier . Soldier A still had his pistol in his hand . He put his hands up in the air and shouted " Police " . A recalled hearing shooting from behind as the police car was approaching .

While neither of the soldiers was aware of the police car or siren until after the shooting , the majority of witnesses , including the police officers P , Q and R who were in the vicinity to support the soldiers in the arrest and a number of the surveillance team as well as civilian witnesses , recalled that the sound of the police siren preceded , if only by a very short time , the sound of the gunfire . Officers P and Q , who were watching from a relatively close distance , considered that ORG and PERSON reacted to the sound of the siren : Q was of the opinion that it was the siren that caused PERSON and ORG to stop and turn .

CARDINAL . The arrival of the police car at the scene was an unintended occurrence . After the Commissioner had handed over control to the military at TIME , he instructed PERSON to ensure that there was police transport available . PERSON telephoned Chief Inspector PERSON at FAC , who in turn instructed the Controller Police Constable PERSON to recall the duty police car . The ORG recorded the call at TIME . He radioed the patrol car informing the officers that they were to return immediately . He did not know where the car was at the time or what the reason for the recall was . When Inspector PERSON who was in the car asked if it was urgent , the PERSON told him it was a priority message and further instructions would be given on arrival .

CARDINAL . At the time of the message , the police car was waiting in a queue of traffic in ORG . PERSON told the driver to put on siren and beacons . The car pulled out into the opposite lane to overtake the queue of traffic . They cut back into the proper lane at the lights at the junction with PERSON and continued north along FAC in the outer lane . As they passed the ORG garage , the CARDINAL policemen in the car heard shots . PERSON instructed the driver to continue . When he looked back , he saw QUANTITY persons lying on the pavement . The car went round the sundial roundabout and returned to stop on the other side of the road opposite the ORG garage . The police siren was on during this time . CARDINAL . LAW provides :
" CARDINAL . No person shall be deprived of his life intentionally save in execution of the sentence of a court in respect of a criminal offence of which he has been convicted .

CARDINAL . A person shall not be regarded as having been deprived of his life in contravention of this section if he dies as a result of the use to such extent and in such circumstances as are permitted by law , of such force as is reasonably justifiable :
( a ) for the defence of any person from violence or for the defence of property ;
( b ) in order to effect a lawful arrest or to prevent the escape of a person lawfully detained ;
( d ) in order to prevent the commission by that person of a criminal offence . "

CARDINAL . The relevant domestic case - law establishes that the reasonableness of the use of force has to be decided on the basis of the facts which the user of the force honestly believed to exist : this involves the subjective test as to what the user believed and an objective test as to whether he had reasonable grounds for that belief . Given that honest and reasonable belief , it must then be determined whether it was reasonable to use the force in question in the prevention of crime or to effect an arrest ( see , for example , ORG v. ORG [ DATE ] ORG CARDINAL ; R v. PERSON [ DATE ] CARDINAL Criminal Appeal Reports CARDINAL , at p. CARDINAL ; and R v. PERSON [ DATE ] ORG CARDINAL , at p. CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The test of whether the use of force is reasonable , whether in self - defence or to prevent crime or effect an arrest , is a strict CARDINAL . It was described in the following terms in the report of ORG appointed to consider the law relating to indictable offences ( [ DATE ] CARDINAL ORG CARDINAL , at p. CARDINAL ) :

" We take one great principle of the common law to be , that though it sanctions the defence of a man ’s person , liberty and property against illegal violence , and permits the use of force to prevent crimes to preserve the public peace and to bring offenders to justice , yet all this is subject to the restriction that the force used is necessary ; that is , that the mischief sought to be prevented could not be prevented by less violent means ; and that the mischief done by or which might reasonably be anticipated from the force used is not disproportionate to the injury or mischief , which it is intended to prevent . "
Lord Justice McGonigal in Attorney General for GPE Reference ( [ DATE ] ORG CARDINAL ( ORG ) ) stated his understanding of this approach as follows ( at p. CARDINAL ) :

" ... it appears to me that , when one is considering whether force used in any particular circumstances was reasonable , the test of reasonableness should be determined in the manner set out in that paragraph . It raises CARDINAL questions :
( a ) Could the mischief sought to be prevented have been prevented by less violent means ?
( b ) Was the mischief done or which could reasonably be anticipated from the force used disproportionate to the injury or mischief which it was intended to prevent ?

These are questions to be determined objectively but based on the actions of reasonable men who act in the circumstances and in the light of the beliefs which the accused honestly believed existed and held . ORG is not reasonable if
( a ) greater than that necessary , or
( b ) if the injury it causes is disproportionately greater than the evil to be prevented . "

CARDINAL . Also attached to the operational order was a guide to police officers in the use of firearms which read :
" Firearms : Use by Police .

The object of any police firearms operation is that the armed criminal is arrested with the least possible danger to all concerned . It is the first duty of the police to protect the general public , but the police should not endanger their lives or the lives of their colleagues for the sake of attempting to make an early arrest . The physical welfare of a criminal armed with a firearm should not be given greater consideration than that of a police officer , and unnecessary risks must not be taken by the police . In their full use of firearms , as in the use of any force , the police are controlled by the restrictions imposed by the law . The most important point which emerges from any study of the law on this subject is that the responsibility is an individual one . Any police officer who uses a firearm may be answerable to the courts or to a coroner ’s inquest and , if his actions were unlawful ( or improper ) , then he as an individual may be charged with murder , manslaughter or unlawful wounding . Similarly , if his use of a firearm was unlawful or negligent the individual could find himself defending a civil case in which substantial damages were being claimed against him . That a similar claim could be made against the Commissioner of Police will not relieve the individual of his liabilities .

The fact that a police officer used his firearms under the orders of a superior does not , of itself , exempt him from criminal liability . When a police officer is issued with a firearm he is not thereby given any form of authority to use it otherwise than strictly in accordance with the law . Similarly , when an officer is briefed about an operation , information about a criminal may indicate that he is desperate and dangerous . Whilst this will be CARDINAL of the factors to consider it does not of itself justify shooting at him .

The final responsibility for his actions rests on the individual and therefore the final decision about whether a shot will or will not be fired at a particular moment can only be made by the individual . That decision must be made with a clear knowledge of the law on the subject and in the light of the conditions prevailing at the time . "
